Graphs

1. The Cartesian plane


ID is: 2120 Seed is: 4930

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points. The points are labelled A,B,CA,B,C and DD.

Which of the points has the coordinates (−4;3)(−4;3)?

Answer: The point at (−4;3)(−4;3) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (−4;3)(−4;3) refer to the point where x=−4x=−4 and y=3y=3.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

There are four points shown in the picture above, and we must decide which of the points has the coordinates (−4;3)(−4;3). Coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. In this case that means that x=−4x=−4 and y=3y=3.

To find where the point is, we always start at the centre point, which is called the "origin." From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

The arrows below show how to get from the origin to the coordinates (−4;3)(−4;3).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (−4;3)(−4;3), xx is −4−4: that means go 44 steps to the left (we go left because the coordinate is negative). After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is 33, which means we need to go up 33 spaces (we go up because the coordinate is positive).

The point at the coordinates (−4;3)(−4;3) is point A.

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points. The points are labelled A,B,CA,B,C and DD.

Which of the points has the coordinates (1;0)(1;0)?

Answer: The point at (1;0)(1;0) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (1;0)(1;0) refer to the point where x=1x=1 and y=0y=0.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

There are four points shown in the picture above, and we must decide which of the points has the coordinates (1;0)(1;0). Coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. In this case that means that x=1x=1 and y=0y=0.

To find where the point is, we always start at the centre point, which is called the "origin." From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

There is an arrow on the graph below which shows how to get from the origin to the point at the coordinates (1;0)(1;0).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (1;0)(1;0), xx is 11: that means go 11 steps to the right (we go right because the coordinate is positive). After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is zero, which means that we do not move up or down: just stay put!

The point at the coordinates (1;0)(1;0) is point B.

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points. The points are labelled A,B,CA,B,C and DD.

Which of the points has the coordinates (0;0)(0;0)?

Answer: The point at (0;0)(0;0) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (0;0)(0;0) refer to the point where x=0x=0 and y=0y=0.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

There are four points shown in the picture above, and we must decide which of the points has the coordinates (0;0)(0;0). Coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. In this case that means that x=0x=0 and y=0y=0.

To find where the point is, we always start at the centre point, which is called the "origin." From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

We want the point at (0;0)(0;0): the zeroes says to us, "do not go anywhere, man!" So the point that we want is at the starting point (at the origin). You can see this shown about on the graph.

The point at the coordinates (0;0)(0;0) is point B.

Coordinates on the Cartesian plane

Four points, labelled M,N,PM,N,P and QQ, are shown below. Answer the two questions below based on this figure.

  1. What is the yy-coordinate of Point NN?

    Answer: The yy-coordinate of Point NN is:
    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Notice that you only the yy-coordinate for the point. Remember that the yy-value for the point tells you how far up or down the point is from the origin.

    STEP: Start at the origin and find the yy-coordinate of Point NN
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need the yy-coordinate of Point NN. There are different ways to think about this question, so you might solve it differently to the explanation here.

    Remember that the yy-coordinate for the point tells us how far up or down the point is from the origin. The horizontal line below passes through Point NN: we can use the line to figure out how far up the point is from the origin.

    As noted in the picture, the horizontal line shows that Point NN is 66 spaces above the origin. In fact, any point on that line is 66 spaces above the origin. That means that the yy-coordinate must be 66.

    The yy-coordinate of Point NN is: y=6y=6.

  2. How many labelled points are there in the second quadrant?

    Answer: The number of labelled points is:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    The question specifically asks us to count how many labelled points are in the second quadrant. The graph shows points M,N,PM,N,P and QQ: how many of them are "in the second quadrant?"
    STEP: Consider the labelled points on the plane
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to figure out how many labelled points there are in the second quadrant. There are only four labelled points in the diagram: how many of them are in the second quadrant?

    In this question, the four points M,N,PM,N,P and QQ are labelled, but they are not the only points on the graph. The Cartesian plane is made of an infinite number of points: they are everywhere!

    The second quadrant is shaded in the figure below: how many of the four labelled points are there in that shaded area? (Note that the quadrants do not include the axes, just like the inequality x>0x>0 does not include the number zero.)

    There is only one labelled point in the second quadrant.

    The correct answer from the list of choices is: 1 point.

Coordinates on the Cartesian plane

Four points, labelled M,N,PM,N,P and QQ, are shown below. Answer the two questions below based on this figure.

  1. What is the xx-coordinate of Point MM?

    Answer: The xx-coordinate of Point MM is:
    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Notice that you only the xx-coordinate for the point. Remember that the xx-value for the point tells you how far to the left or right the point is from the origin.

    STEP: Start at the origin and find the xx-coordinate of Point MM
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need the xx-coordinate of Point MM. There are different ways to think about this question, so you might solve it differently to the explanation here.

    Remember that the xx-coordinate for the point tells us how far to the left or right the point is from the origin. The vertical line below passes through Point MM: we can use the line to figure out how far to the right or left the point is from the origin.

    As noted in the picture, the vertical line shows that Point MM did not move left or right from the origin (because it passes through the origin!): it moved zero spaces left or right. That means that the xx-coordinate must be 00.

    The xx-coordinate of Point MM is: x=0x=0.

  2. How many points are there in the fourth quadrant?

    Answer: The number of points is:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    The question asks how many points there are in the fourth quadrant. Remember that it does not matter if a point is labelled or not: it is still there.
    STEP: Consider the points on the plane
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to figure out how many points there are in the fourth quadrant. Notice that we want all of the points that sit in the fourth quadrant: it does not matter whether they are labelled or not!

    In this question, the four points M,N,PM,N,P and QQ are labelled, but they are not the only points on the graph. The Cartesian plane is made of an infinite number of points: they are everywhere!

    The fourth quadrant is shaded in the figure below: how many points are there in that shaded area?

    Remember, we are not just counting labelled points: we need to think of every single point there is in the fourth quadrant. The answer is that there are an infinite number of points in the fourth quadrant: everywhere you see that shaded colour in the picture above, there is a point!

    The correct answer from the list of choices is: infinite number of points.

Coordinate pairs on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and two points. The points are labelled AA and BB.

What are the coordinates of point BB?

INSTRUCTION: Type your answer as a coordinate pair in brackets, with the values separated by a semi-colon e.g. (x; y)
Answer: The coordinates of point BB are:
coordinate
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You need to find the xx-coordinate of the point and the yy-coordinate of the point. These numbers show how far the point is from the origin.

STEP: Read the coordinates of the point from the graph
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to find the coordinates of point BB. That means we want to know the xx and yy values which tell us where the point is. In other words, we need to know how far the point is from the origin.

We can find these numbers like the arrows show in the picture below: the arrow pointing to the xx-axis shows that the xx-coordinate is −5−5. The arrow pointing to the yy-axis shows that the yy-coordinate is −6−6.

Notice that the xx-value shows you how far left or right the point is from the origin, while the yy-value shows how high up or down the point is from the origin.

Remember the order of coordinate pairs: (x;y)(x;y). The xx-coordinate is first and the yy-coordinate is second.

The coordinates of point BB are: (−5;−6)(−5;−6).

ID is: 2135 Seed is: 5695

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points: A,B,CA,B,C, and DD.

Which of the points is at (−5;−4)(−5;−4)?

Answer: The point at (−5;−4)(−5;−4) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (−5;−4)(−5;−4) refer to the point where x=−5x=−5 and y=−4y=−4.

STEP: Locate the position of (−5;−4)(−5;−4), starting at the origin
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We must decide which of the points has the coordinates (−5;−4)(−5;−4). Remember that coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. Therefore (−5;−4)(−5;−4) means that x=−5x=−5 and y=−4y=−4.

We always start at the origin, which is the point in the centre where the xx-axis and the yy-axis meet. From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

The arrows below show how to get from the origin to the coordinates (−5;−4)(−5;−4).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (−5;−4)(−5;−4), xx is −5−5: that means go 55 steps to the left (we go left because the coordinate is negative). After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is −4−4, which means we need to go down 44 spaces (we go down because the coordinate is negative).

The point at the coordinates (−5;−4)(−5;−4) is point D.

Minimum and maximum values of points on the Cartesian plane

Four points are graphed on the Cartesian plane. They are labelled M,N,PM,N,P, and QQ. Answer the two questions below about these points.

  1. Which point or points have the minimum yy-value?
  2. What is the minimum yy-value of the point(s) you chose to answer Question 1?
Answer:
  1. The point or points which have the minimum yy-value are: .
  2. The minimum yy-value is: .
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The question asks about the minimum yy-value for the four points shown. That means the lowest points on the graph (the ones furthest down).

STEP: Look for the points with the minimum yy-value
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to find the minimum yy-value of the four points on the graph. Remember that the yy-coordinate describes how far up or down something is from the origin: the "minimum yy-value" means the point furthest down on the graph.

The horizontal line below shows the boundary at the minimum yy-value. As explained on the graph, there are no points lower than this boundary line: that is why the line represents the minimum yy-value of the four points.

There is only one point at the minimum yy-value: P.

STEP: Read the minimum yy-value from the Cartesian plane
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Finding the minimum yy-value for the four points comes straight from the graph above: the horizontal line shows the minimum value, which is y=−8y=−8!

This means that the point P has a yy-coordinate equal to −8−8 and none of the other four points have yy-coordinates less than −8−8.

The minimum yy-value for the four points on the graph is y=−8y=−8.

Reading graphs: making ice

Imagine that you put water into an ice tray and then put the tray into the freezer. The water starts to get colder, and after a bit of time the water will freeze into ice cubes. (Water freezes at 0°C0°C.) After all of the water is frozen, the temperature continues to go down.

The graph here shows what happens to the temperature of the water as it freezes into ice cubes.

  1. After how many minutes does the water begin to freeze?
  2. Estimate the temperature of the water after 55 minutes.
Answer:
  1. The water took minutes to freeze.
  2. The temperature after 55 minutes was approximately °C°C.
numeric
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The first question asks you how many minutes it took the water to start freezing. That means you need to figure out how much time passed from the beginning until the water reached a temperature of 0°C0°C.

Reading graphs: connecting the variables

The graph below shows the relationship between the temperature of water in a freezer and time. (The freezing point of water is 0°C0°C.) There are also four points labelled along the line of the graph.

  1. What are the coordinates of Point DD?

    INSTRUCTION: Type your answer in the normal way for coordinate pairs, like this: (1 ; 2). You do not need to put any units in your answer, just numbers.
    Answer: The coordinates of Point DD are: .
    coordinate
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Points on the Cartesian plane always have coordinates like this: (x;y)(x;y). In this graph, "time" is in the place of xx and "temperature" is in the place of yy. You need to find the values of "time" and "temperature" for Point DD.

    STEP: Read the graph
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    We need to find the coordinates for a point on the line. Remember that coordinates on the Cartesian plane always come in the same order: (x;y)(x;y). However, for this graph, "time" is in the place of xx and "temperature" is in the place of yy. That means the coordinates we need are (time;temperature)(time;temperature).

    Point DD is circled below. From the point we need to read the values for the coordinates from each axis.

    Point DD has a time value of 6060 minutes and a value of −10−10 degrees Celsius for temperature. Therefore, the coordinates of Point DD are: (60;−10)(60;−10).

    Submit your answer as:

  2. What is the meaning behind the coordinates of Point DD?

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the meaning of the numbers: for example, the first number in the coordinate pair represents an amount of time.

    STEP: Interpret the meaning of a coordinate pair
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Remember that a graph shows a relationship between two quantities. A coordinate pair connects two values.

    The coordinate pair (60;−10)(60;−10) connects time and the temperature. It tells us that when the time is 6060 minutes the corresponding temperature is −10−10 degrees Celsius.

    Therefore the correct choice is: At the point where time is 6060 minutes, the temperature is −10−10 degrees Celsius.

To earn N=80N=80, Karabou needs approximately 44 hours. (Any answer between 3.93.9 and 4.14.1 is acceptable.)

The graph below shows the relationship between the temperature of water in an electic kettle and time passing. At the beginning, the temperature is 25°C25°C. As time passes, the water heats up until it boils. After boiling, the water cools slowly in the kettle.

STEP: Which quantity is on the yy-axis?
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The graph shows the relationship between two quanities: "time" and "temperature." This is the information on the two axes. This question asks which one of them is on the yy-axis?

The "yy- axis" always refers to the yy- axis on the graph (the axis which goes side to side). The information on that axis is the "temperature."

STEP: Which part of the graph shows the temperature is increasing?

ID is: 2139 Seed is: 1985

Reading graphs: graphs show relationships

The graph here shows the relationship between the temperature of water in a freezer and time. The temperature of the water at the beginning is 25°C25°C, and then the water gets colder. The water then freezes to become ice. After that, the temperature of the ice continues to go down.

Notice that there are also 44 points labelled along the line of the graph.

Answer:
  1. Which quantity is on the dependent axis?
  2. Which part of the graph shows the temperature decreasing?
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
  1. The first question is about the one of the two things related by this graph: "time" and "temperature." Which one of them is on the dependent axis?
  2. For the second question, remember that "decreasing" means going down... what part of the graph, if any, shows the temperature going down?
STEP: Which quantity is on the dependent axis?
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The graph shows the relationship between two quanities: "time" and "temperature." This is the information on the two axes. This question asks which one of them is on the dependent axis?

The words "independent" and "dependent" refer to the variables in the graph. For any graph, one of the variables is going about its business independently while the other vairable "depends" on the first one. Here is a summary:

  • Independant variable: the variable which is in control; it is always on the xx-axis
  • Dependant variable: the variable that follows (responds to) the independent variable; it is always on the yy-axis
In this graph, the independent variable is time because time just moves along: we cannot control it. The dependent variable is temperature because it depends on how much time has passed. Therefore, the correct answer is "temperature."

STEP: Which part of the graph shows the temperature decreasing?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question is about how the temperature is changing: "decreasing" means going down... what part of the graph, if any, shows the temperature going down?

When you put water into a freezer, what happens? The temperature of the water starts to go down because the freezer is... freezing! When the temperature does down, that is decreasing. Then after the water is frozen into ice, the temperature continues to go down. There are two sections on this graph where the temperature is decreasing; they are shown with the large arrows in the picture below.

The correct choice from the list is: from A to B and also from C to D.
